CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Nona Tsotsoria;Vladimiro Zagrebelsky
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant is a professor of construction management at ORG . In his speech , delivered during the “ First National Construction Conference ” , which took place in DATE , the applicant analysed the progress of the work in his field of discipline . He also distributed a paper in which he criticised the way the examinations for assistant professors were being administered .

CARDINAL . On DATE , an assistant professor , N.C.A. , brought a civil action for compensation against the applicant , before ORG . He claimed that certain remarks used by the applicant in the paper constituted an attack on his reputation , although his name was not mentioned . The statements in question were as follows :

“ The panel for the assistant professorship examination in the discipline of construction management was formed by academics of the construction faculty . This led to the election of very inadequate assistant professors . ( ... ) During this period , before a panel on which [ the applicant ] was the only professor of construction management , a candidate was notified that his CARDINAL - page - long report and his examination were not satisfactory . Blaming [ the applicant ] for the unsatisfactory result , the same candidate filed an action for damages , alleging that he had been beaten by [ the applicant ] . Before the action for compensation was finalised , he managed to pass the assistant professorship examination before another panel , whose members were not from the construction management department , and without publishing a single article ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the first instance court rejected ORG 's claim , holding that these statements were merely a criticism of the academic system and the institutions . ORG appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the decision holding that the following sentence could be taken as an attack on the plaintiff 's reputation :

“ ... he managed to pass the assistant professorship examination before another panel , whose members were not from the construction management department , and without publishing a single article ... ”
CARDINAL . It held that the above sentence implied that , if there had been a different panel , the plaintiff would have failed the examination .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's request for rectification of the latter decision was dismissed .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of First instance , after having considered ORG views on the case , confirmed its earlier decision . It held that the defendant , who was an academic , should be granted the flexibility enjoyed by members of the press or lawyers . The reasoning of the court was as follows :

“ If these statements were uttered by a press member or a lawyer , it would have been regarded as freedom of the press or the rights of the defence . If we hold that these remarks made by an academic were against the law , then this would be a breach of his constitutional rights , such as freedom of expression , dissemination of ideas ( article CARDINAL ) and freedom of science and the arts ( DATE ) . ”
CARDINAL . N.A.C. appealed once again . On DATE ORG of the ORG quashed the decision by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL , holding that the first instance court should have followed the opinion of ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's request for the rectification of the latter decision was dismissed .

CARDINAL . The case was resumed before ORG of First Instance . The applicant informed the court that , at DATE , ORG had dismissed ORG from his post on account of his inadequate scientific competence and personal values . In view of this information , the applicant asserted that he had been right to criticise the system of promotion and thus asked the court to dismiss the plaintiff 's request .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first instance court followed the decision of ORG of ORG , and awarded ORG compensation in the sum of MONEY ( TRL ) for non - pecuniary damage . The court did not address the applicant 's argument concerning the dismissal of the plaintiff from the university . Both parties appealed against this decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE Court of Cassation upheld the decision of the first instance court .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's request for rectification of the decision of DATE was rejected by ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicant was ordered to pay GPE CARDINAL , the sum obtained by adding together the principal compensation , interest and court fees .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Obligations provides as follows :
“ Any person who alleges that his personality rights have been illegally violated can claim compensation for non - pecuniary damage .
The judge shall take into account the parties ' socio - economic situation , their occupation and social status when determining the amount of compensation ... ”
CARDINAL . In its LAW ( DATE ) , ORG of ORG adopted the following declaration for the protection of academic freedom of expression :
CARDINAL . In accordance with the Magna Charta GPE , the ORG reaffirms the right to academic freedom and university autonomy which comprises the following principles :

CARDINAL . academic freedom in research and in training should guarantee freedom of expression and of action , freedom to disseminate information and freedom to conduct research and distribute knowledge and truth without restriction ; ...
CARDINAL . history has proven that violations of academic freedom and university autonomy have always resulted in intellectual relapse , and consequently in social and economic stagnation ; ... ”
